Reading numbers

The value returned by next() is always of type String. But if you are working with numbers, that's not very convenient, because you can't do math with Strings.

In the last lab, you saw how to use a method such as Integer.parseInt to convert a string to an integer. The Scanner class provides additional methods that are specialized for reading different types of values: nextInt() for reading integers and nextDouble() for reading floating-point values. For example, here is a simple main class that reads two integers from the keyboard and prints their product: 

package lab4;
import java.util.Scanner;

public class Multiplier
{
  public static void main(String[] args)
  {
    Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);
    System.out.print("Enter a number: ");
    int first = scanner.nextInt();
    System.out.print("Enter a number: ");
    int second = scanner.nextInt();
    int result = first * second;
    System.out.println(first + " times " + second + " is " + result);
  }
}

Create the Multiplier class in Eclipse and run it.
